text: Pours a dark brown color with a small pillowy head that lasts throughout. Light aromas of caramel, nuts and some chocolate. Mild (thus the name) flavors of caramel, nuts, chocolate, a little smoke and musty hay/grass. Medium-bodied with a fairly bitter finish. A pleasant beer from start from finish

Bottle. Very dark brown in colour, with slightly reddish hue. Very malty; roasty malts, chocolate, caramel. Hoppy; earthy grassy hops. Porterish in style. Roasty chocolate malty balanced by hop bitterness throughout. Dry mildly bitter finish. Tasty. Liked this a lot. Nice beer! (2009-02)

500ml bottle at home, present from Stuartyboy, roast malt, caramel aroma, very deep chestnut brown with a good bubbly beige head, coffee, chocolate flavour, subtle smoke, creamy, earthy malty aftertaste.
500ml bottle at home. Pours dark brown black with a dissipating off white head. Aroma of malt with some roast. Bitter sweet finish.
Nowt like a few pints of ghost on a dark winters night in York. Bottle doesnt quite do it but still good.
Bottle from bier huis, Ossett. Very dark brown beer with small head. Aroma is roasted malts and caramel. Taste is roasted malts, caramel, a little smoke and chalky. Medium bodied. Very nice.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: 500ml bottle. Dark brown-black ruby colour, foamy white head with mash malty caramel type aroma. Malty dry fizzy bitterness followed by roast caramel, biscuit, coffee notes and remaining fairly dry with slight sweetish and lingering bitterness. Quite OK.
0,5l fles meegebracht uit York. Donker bruin bier met een witte kraag. Geur van geroosterde mout en brood. Mondgevoel is licht plakkend, smaak is bitterzoet, aangenaam bittertje in de afdronk.

One of my first mild ales, this beer pours with a thick creamy head which blasts the aroma of roasted malt and bitter dark chocolate into your face, just inviting you in. the mouthfeel is quite slick and oily but it hold a robust flavour the malt content reduces the bitterness to a minimal bite as an after taste. Smooth and rich it is a great mild for any dark beer newcomer.
Pours a dark brown colour with a thin beige head, mild malty aroma, the taste is light sweetness, with roasted malt with a dry finish.

Medium beige head. Clear barely translucent dark brown body. Roasty earthy aroma with dusty burnt notes. Sweetish roasty nutty earthy taste with fruity notes. Mid-bodied. Mild, soft mouthfeel. Dryish minty fruity roasty aftertaste with spicy earthy oily rye crisp bread notes. Nice, vivid, and highly drinkable. (0.5l bottle, from House of Trembling Madness, York.)
A fine mild ale, not completely black in appearance but getting there. Has a medium to full body with plenty of mild but good tasting roasted notes

500ml Bottle:BBD 28 Jul 2013. Shared with the wife on 14 Jun 2013. Poured into two old Home Ales half-pint countryman tankards.

Dark, very dark: ruby red hints in the light, good tanned head that lasted on both halves.

Malty aroma and taste: charcoal and chocolate infused coffee, all rolled up in a caramel flavoured brown bread bap. Then soaked over night in alcohol, great!

Smooth, complex and tasty, more malts obviously than hops, but the hops do keep the sweetness in check nicely.

Good body feel and depth: a very pleasant beer all round.

Bottled	25/05/13.  A near blak coloured beer with an off-white head.  Roasted malts and a little banana in the nose.  Chocolate and light coffee and coal fires in the mouth with a little sweetness.  More like an old ale for me.  Enjoyable.

500ml bottle - Dark mahogany body with a light tan head. Raisin, apple, cherry and pine in the aroma. Chocolate hops and malt dominate the taste, some light coffee. Nice bitter ending. Felt closer to a stout than a mild.

My kind of beer. Too easy to drink at 5.4%, this is a dark mild cum porter. Pours darkest brown with light carbonation. Aroma is of roasted chestnuts and coffee. The palate is well balanced with subtle hops that linger after the chocolate and smoke finally disappear. Very good!

Dark brown with ruby highlights, gentle carbonation, chocolate, coffee. Astringency in the middle followed by red berries in the finish.

Dark brown almost black with a red tint. and a thin dissapearing tan lacy head. Smells of light roast chocolate malt, fruit and sweet malt. Frothy medium sticky body. Nice solid old ale. Taste of nice sweet cherry, rasin, caramel and a lasting bitter chocolate roast finish. Kept drinking it. Truly excellent.

500ml bottle served cellar cool in a large tulip. Fruity malty aroma, beautiful darkest brown body with a dense and lasting tan head. What really impresses is the balance: from the first sip, I expected some robust smokiness, but what it actually delivers is a lovely plummy juiciness on the swallow. Lots biscuity malt, dried fruit, and a hint of licquorice. Delicious.

Bottle 500ml.Clear light dark red brown colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, smoke notes. Flavour is moderate to light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, roasted, sweet malt, tobacco, thin coffee notes. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20120331]

Bottle 50 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours a clear brown with an orange hue and a small beige head. Roasty nose with a little sweet licorice. Medium body, hard roast malt, a slightly tart woody note or something. Some dark dried fruit. Surprisingly bitter finish. Nice one. 020412

50 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden deep amber with a small tan head. Toasted malty and crisp hoppy. Toasted malty and light breadish. Caramelish and crisp hoppy. Bitter and dry roasted malty finish.
Bottle @ Fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are burnt caramel, roast malt, notes of cofee and hops.

Bottle @ FOneFan. Dark brown/red with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, dark fruits, caramel and yeast. Flavour is malt, chocolate, dark fruits, medium sweet, little coffee, hops and a little bitter.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Clear reddish brown with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and dried fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish. 310312

500ml500ml bottle. Really deep brown, almost black with a rich tan head producing plenty of lacing. Deep roasts of malts, toffees, chocolate and woodyness. On the tongue this opens out a bit more to include licorice, sweet caramels and some bitter hoppy notes. A heavy, full drink but theres no alcohol bitterness just a warming drink packed full of flavour. Really rich, full finish. Lovely.

500ml bottle. Pours a deep brown with two fingers of head. Laces all the way down the glass. Chocolate, cola, blackberries. Deep and chewy with plenty of roastiness. Hard one to categorise into a particular style, but a very good beer regardless.

Love this - well distinguished flavours and a great colour. Warming and tasty

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
cask in Market Porter London, awesome ale, quite heavy to drink but full of taste, medium bitterness, light sweetness, nice hazy amber-dark colour, long finish. lovely beer
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: From Tesco, Thirsk. Aromas of coffee, chocolate and toffee transfer well into the flavour. Its smooth, stroing flavoured and mellow, with a deep ruby appearance and foamy pale coffee coloured head. Malt dominates throughout, the strength is subtle, but its a beer full of body and character. Long aftertaste with a hint of bitterness, blackcurrant and roast malt appear very late on.

Bottle shared with my mate paddy watching United. Poured dark brown with a thin tan head. Light bitterness, bit of hops, tobacco, dandelion and burdock. Drinkable, not usually mystyle but quite enjoyed it.

Bottle from Sainsburys. Dark brown pour (almost black) with a beige head. Raisins, chocolate, berry and caramel aromas. Coffee and chocolate malt flavours with a tinge of smoke. Dry, slightly bitter-sweet finish. Not bad at all
Bottle.  Molasses, prune and alcohol aroma.  Dark brown color with minimal head.  Slightly sweet raisin, chocolate malt and moderately bitter grass hop flavor.  A bit light but nice.

Very deep mahogany colour. Almost black with an off white head clinging to glass. Sweet caramel aroma. Altogether quite rich. Strong caramel malt flavour. Hints of roasted malt and chocolate. Nice bitter finish.
Bottle. Thin off white head. Black body. Some spiciness, chocolate, nuts, roastiness, malt, pine, spruce. Bitter. Medium to heavy. Astringent finish. Some oiliness.

Bottle.

A - Dark mahogany with definite ruby streaks. Full, large, frothy, creamy, sticky, off cream color with very good retention leaving a thick layer of creamy lace.

S - Sweet, earthy nut flavors strongest with some background hints of chocolate. Some strong dark and caramel malt aroma as well. Very faint dark fruit (and general fruitiness) underneath it all.

T - Interesting mix of different English flavors. Initially there is a lot of earthy and nutty taste with mild dark and caramel malt bringing some sweetness. Some chocolate malt and a bit of a roasted feel, somewhat similar to an English Stout with more coming out mid-sip. Some grassy and earthy hops come out.

M - Medium to light body with a little below average carbonation. Fairly smooth.

D - Quite drinkable with a nice mix of dark mild and stout flavors. Light and easy on the tongue but it has enough complexity to be interesting that builds as you drink it.

Notes: Best before 28/August/2010. Very enjoyable beer to drink. Its definitely English although I dont think it fits neatly into a style. Well balanced and very enjoyable beer. Worth grabbing one if you can.

Bottle 500 ml from Fabeers in York. Dark ale, a bit muddy, thin beige foam. The roasted malt dominates with chocolate keys and molasses. Light bitterness, measured well, notes of dates, toast and grapes on malted cream. Solid body. A bit sweetness in this bitter country. Aftertaste of fruit, licorice and bitterness.

Bottle. Pours a very dark, opaque brown with a really fine beige head that soon disperses. Aromas are very distant with just a touch of fig coming through the otherwise quite full and musty base. Fruity with some raisin notes, a creamy malt tone and lightly toasted malt flavours, finishing with liquorice notes on the swallow. Medium body and a bit of fizz there on the palate.

Bottle, from Sainsburys Grimsby. Deep red-black, thin but lasting creamy white head, moderate condition. Gentle sweet smokiness initially in the nose with some plummy fruitiness and a touch of roasted barley, full and roasty in the mouth with bitter coffee notes and gently fruitiness followed by some toffee sweetness and a gentle herby hoppiness, some lingering dry roasted bitterness and gentle figginess in the finish.

De couleur très foncée et rougeatre, cette english ale est très maltée. Elle a des flaveurs de malt, de vanille, de boisé et de jambon fumé. Plutot lourde et sucrée, elle peut finir par tomber un peu sur le coeur.
UPDATED: AUG 10, 2014 Deep red-brown colour. Rich texture. A little toasty malt at first. Some dark fruit sweetness too.
Aroma of malt and coffee. Coke colour with a thin off white head. Some lacing on the glass. Flavour of malt and chocolate. Thick and smooth
Black/brown in colour with a quickly diminishing head.  Toasty aroma.  Flavour is mid sweet with a dark caramel flavour.  Seriously good.

Bottle, Evil Eye, York, Dark brown, almost black coloured with very little to no carbonation and a small brown head. Roasted malty smouth aroma with a full palate. Finish is again some roasted malty touches with some toffee hints. Medium one.
scura schiuma media persitente sentori di malto luppolo in bocca malto tostato luppolo caramello piuttosto secca liquirizia non molto corpo tostato lungo

Clear deep brown body with ruby highlights and a small tan head. Sweet floral and earthy hop aroma with some caramel and molassas. Sweet molassas, caramel, chocolate and peat flavors with some floral hops. Medium body with moderately low carbonation and a earthy finish.

Deep dark amber colored with little yellow head. Licorice dominates this sweet aroma with caramel and mild hops. Medium bodied. Flavor is more dry with some cardboard, also mild licorice note here with some caramel. Aftertaste has also this slight cardboard. Good one, at least aroma-wise.

For a year and a half old bottle this is still surprisingly fresh.  Nice dark ruby color with a slight white head.  Light aroma, some malts and light grass still evident.  Taste is mostly smoked malts with a very light fruit accent.  Ending is somewhat smooth.  I really dont think this is an ESB as it has held up WAY too well... maybe a Brown Ale would be a better category.
Tap/draught Slightly sweet and smoky with fruity flavors.Slightly bitter in finish. Very good.

Bottled. Dark brown with amber notes. Low grey head. Dark chocolate, cherries and grass in the aroma. Grainy flavour of caramel, dark chocolate and dried fruit. Grassy bitter finish with touches of cocoa.

Bottle. Dark brown with a beige creamy  head that started out quite big. Roasted malts and fruits nose with hints of licorice. Burnt caramel flavours, smoked malts, good balance. Velvety. An exciting blend of a mild and a rauchbier.

Sweet caramel licorice nose. Smooth boozy smoky malt. Sweet stout? Heady mild? The mellow roast and sneaking inebriation of a sweet Belgian Bruin (Special Katje, bellegems?). Sweetly stouty, malty bitter with the easy drinkability of a beer a couple of percent weaker.

Bottle from Onlyfinebeer. Dark brown with an off-white slim head. Aroma has sweet malts, caramel, and chocolate. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee & chocolate with a nice bitter finish. Light to medium bodied, moderate carbonation. Good bitter; very good for a pasteurised one.
A dark coloured ale with a slight nuttiness. Creamy mouthfeel and plenty of body.Nice.

From A Bottle.Reddish brown in colour with a small head,
aroma is sweet and malty,taste is sweet with dark malt and some bitterness in the finish.

Bottled, Pasteurised. Dark brown with a red hue, little head. The pasteurisation process has lost the subtleties of the cask, this is a plainish dark ale with a heavy chocolate malt, sweetish and full. Little hop character comes through.
Clear but very dark brown coloured. Chocolate, coffee and roated malts in aroma. Flavour however is really watery. Finishes bitter. Probably their best brew.
A fairly good but rather one-dimensional strong ale, a little too sweet and fruity for me - needs a bit more hoppy bitterness to make it truly interesting.
A dark purple-brown beer.  This has a musty fruit aroma that is redeemed by dry, licourice notes.  Nothing special, nothing bad.  Yawn.
Falls in between a robust bitter and a light English strong ale.
